title: New Zealand kayaker takes on Iceland's epic 'Waterfall of Thieves'
text:
New Zealand kayaker takes on Iceland's epic 'Waterfall of Thieves' Last updated 16:04, September 11 2015 BEN BROWN/Supplied 
New Zealand kayaker Ben Brown and Anton Immler visit Iceland, a waterfall kayaking mecca. 
The breathtaking landscapes of Iceland provides extreme thrill-seekers with a plethora of adventures, especially when it comes to kayaking. 
Covered in ice, glaciers and geysers, Iceland is home to a massive glaciated icecap that melts during the spring and summer months. The melt then transforms the landscape into incredible gushing waterfalls that sprout in every direction towards the sea. 
It is for this very reason that, as well as being one of the most beautiful countries on earth, Iceland is also known as a kayaking "mecca". Something kayakers, Ben Brown and Anton Immler, only know too well. Screen Grab 
Covered in ice, glaciers and geysers, Iceland is home to a massive glaciated icecap that melts during the spring and summer months. The melt then transforms the landscape into incredible gushing waterfalls that sprout in every direction towards the sea. 
The adventurous duo recently circumnavigated the country in a bid to discover its natural wonders, and being avid kayakers, it's only natural they also picked off some classic waterfalls along the way.

"Our first stop was the waterfall Thjofafoss which translates to the 'Waterfall of Thieves' - it got its name from Pagan times, when thieves were drowned in the waterfall for their crimes. It is approximately 14 meters tall and is more impressive for its volume of water, rather than its height." Brown told RedBull.com 
"Former athlete Shaun Baker nearly drowned in this waterfall many years ago leading to it also being known as drowning drop in kayaking circles." 
From Thjofafoss, Ben and Anton drove to the iceberg forest, also known as Jökulsárlón glacier lagoon.Jökulsárlón sits at the foot of the Vatnajökull Glacier. Ad Feedback 
With a surface area of 8,100 km2, it is Europe's largest glacier outside the arctic, and at over 248 meters deep, it was also recently became the deepest lake in Iceland. 
What makes this epic feat even more incredible is that Brown is back doing what he loves just 11 months after a full shoulder reconstruction. - Stuff
